minecraft:written_book_content.title: A Witch's Guide to Brewing Ed. 1
minecraft:written_book_content.author: Crimsoff
pages: To get started, you need a Witch’s Cauldron. To get a Witch’s Cauldron, you need to throw some anointing paste into a regular cauldron. The paste can be crafted using the four vanilla seed types, or the four vanilla fungus types.

pages.text: To function, a Witch’s Cauldron must be filled with water and heated by a fire. Cauldrons have a limited number of effects and modifiers they can use, determined by their capacity. The capacity of a cauldron starts at 1, increased by adding mandrake roots or nether wart.

Each new effect uses up capacity. Glowstone can increase the power of the previous effect but uses up capacity. Redstone can increase the duration of an effect. Not every effect can have its power or duration increased.

The color of a cauldron’s brew can be changed any time with dye. Gunpowder turns a potion into its splash variant. Clay will absorb the potion inside, clearing the cauldron. Otherwise, a bottle can be used to collect the brew.

Sugar gives speed
Blaze powder gives strength
Golden carrots give night vision
Glass gives invisibility
Rabbit’s foot gives luck
Rabbit hide gives jump boost
Magma cream gives fire resistance
String gives slowness

Pufferfish gives water breathing
Glistering melon slices give instant health
Pointed dripstone gives instant damage
Spider eyes give poison
Ghast tears give regeneration
Fermented spider eyes give weakness
Phantom membranes give slow falling

Breeze rods give wind charged
Cobwebs give weaving
Slime blocks give oozing
Stone gives infested
Wither roses give wither
Apples give absorption
Closed eye blossoms give blindness
Open eye blossoms give nausea
Popped chorus fruits give levitation

Dandelions give saturation
Sculk gives darkness
Tropical fish give dolphin’s grace
